reporting-org.narrative: Association for Women's Rights in Development (AWID)

description.narrative: 1. Strengthening the safety, wellbeing and resilience of partners. 2. Capacity-strengthening for L&A including social advocacy43 to improve partners’ capacities to successfully lobby political leaders, societal actors and donors, including with CMI! members. 3. Cross-movement alliance building.
Structurally excluded women and girls (women, girls, and non-binary, gender non-conforming, trans, and intersex people)

Through movement building, CMI! will engage in Cross movement alliance building to develop mutually supportive relationships between CMI! members and to partner with allies and potential allies. emergency interventions and take advantage of political opportunities to advance the rights of women and girls.

participating-org.narrative: Association for Women's Rights in Development (AWID)
Association for Women's Rights in Development (AWID)

title.narrative: 1. WHRDs and WROs are resourced, coordinated and resilient.

description.narrative: 1. WHRDs and WROs are resourced, coordinated and resilient.
This indicator measures the number of strengthened alliances and or new alliances created through CMI member interventions
The indicator collects qualitative information on the types of alliances that have been created by CMI members

comment.narrative: Strengthened alliance: Feminists for a Binding Treaty - this is a global alliance of feminists, women’s rights groups and civil society allies from all over the world call on governments to support the legally-binding instrument on transnational corporations and human rights. AWID and our allies already see evidence of feminist demands influencing the advocacy messages and demands of the wider Treaty Alliance and other INGOs advocating in that space too. We have contributed feminist analysis to a range of related conversations, including with the Global Initiative for Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (IG-ESCR), the Center for Economic and Social Rights (CESR)’s 'Rights-Based Economy' reference group (January), ActionAid’s report series on “Another world is possible: Advancing feminist economic alternatives to secure rights, justice and autonomy for women and a fair, green, gender-equal world. New alliance: CMI! supported the establishment of the initiative called ‘Feminist Action for Afghanistan’ to coordinate efforts and identify how to support Afghan feminists and the Afghan women’s rights movement. AWID provided the capacity to set up the infrastructure; UAF and Mama Cash supported partners and WHRDs in relocation efforts, and WO=MEN linked global advocacy with their national lobby efforts towards the Dutch government to ensure WHRDs were recognised as a risk category for evacuation.

title.narrative: 2.1 WHRDs and WROs report that their movements are strong and autonomous.

description.narrative: The indicator contains qualitative information that WHRDs and WROs report that their movements are strong and autonomous.

comment.narrative:
Nearly 1,500 feminists came together virtually at convenings designed to build & strengthen learning, and solidarity and build cross-movement alliances.
● Curated conversations on “What has Feminism Got to do with it?”, “Movement as Healing: an online convening of 30 healers and activists (by invitation only)”, and “No Borders, No Walls: Feminist for Abolition” (23 participants). ● A month-long feminist festival where 130 activists from 43 countries held 40 sessions to celebrate and transform movements. There were 2,800+ views on our YouTube channel, and the hashtag #FeministFestival reached two million people over a six-month period (including the lead up and post festival period).
(June) Publication: Second Trends report: Rights at Risk, Time for Action - downloaded 225+ times. >60% are from Grassroots, Social movements, NGO and/or INGOs. 50% say they plan to use the resource as a tool for advocacy. ● Also published a policy brief in November to continue building knowledge on how to counter the strategies & tactics of anti-rights actors.
Strengthened the collective power of young feminists by supporting their strategizing, organizing and learning during the GEF process where young feminist were formally involved and also held a 3-day Young Feminist Unconference (June) in Paris attended by over 100 young feminists.

title.narrative: 3. Space for feminist demands and influence is sustained and increased.

comment.narrative: Supported young feminists to defend youth-lead spaces at the GEF process while creating their own space to centre young feminist demands.

title.narrative: 5. Political actors, societal actors and donors support laws, policies and strategies promoting women’s and girls’*rights.

description.narrative: 5. Political actors, societal actors and donors support laws, policies and strategies promoting women’s and girls’*rights.

title.narrative: 5.1 # of laws, policies and strategies blocked, adopted and improved

description.narrative: The indicator measures the number of laws, policies and strategies blocked, adopted and improved

title.narrative: 5.2 Types of laws, policies and strategies blocked, adopted or improved

description.narrative: This qualitative indicator measures the types of law, policies and strategies blocked, adopted or improved

comment.narrative: Expanded and more nuanced understanding of gender: AWID organized several events to launch the second Trends report by AWID and the Observatory on the Universality of Rights (OURs) - Rights at Risk: Time for Action - and its key messages with as many audiences as possible, including during the UN CSW 65, at the Global Philanthropy Project’s Shimmering Solidarity Summit, and through a press briefing in partnership with openDemocracy 50.50. Preliminary data from users downloading the report to date suggest that the majority are using the report to learn about anti rights strategies and feminist resistance, while about half intend to use the resource as a tool for advocacy. AWID has developed an eight-page brief as well to make our analysis more accessible, with the intent of encouraging policymakers to engage with the content and access the full report; and, that it will be a useful advocacy tool for activists. We are repeatedly hearing positive feedback about the usefulness of the report from UN officials and mandate holders, international development agencies, as well as feminist, women's rights and LGBTQI+ rights organizations.

Advancing new policies, laws or norms (by donors, political, societal actors) in relation to women’s and girls‘ rights. OR • Successful passing of a proposal for improvement of existing policy, law or norm (for donors, political or societal actors). OR • Expanded and more nuanced understanding of gender , OR • Successful blocking of a policy, law or norm (for donors, political or societal actors) that would have negatively impacted on the rights of women and girls.
